item.title: Calculus - Integral
item.description:
The knowledge marked with * is not necessary in Calculus II

WHY: Why do we want to find out the integral

  • Find out the area
  • Find out some physics parameters

WHAT: What is integral - “Area (with positive and negative)”

Approx. Integral

Equaling space is not necessary

Dividing a function and approx it to separated rectangles, then just calculate the areas of rectangles:

$$ S (\int_a^b{f(x)}dx) = \lim_{n \rarr \infin} \sum_{i = 0}^{n - 1} \Delta x f(x_i) = \lim_{n \rarr \infty}{\sum_{i = 0}^{n - 1}\frac{b - a}{n}f(a + \frac{b - a}{n}i)} $$

eg. $$ \int_0^1{x^9} = \frac{1}{n}((\frac{1}{n})^9 + (\frac{2}{n})^9 + \ldots + (\frac{n}{n})^9) $$

  • Riemann integral: left, right, midpoint = $f((x_1 + x_2)/2)$
  • Trapezoidal = (left + right)/2
  • Simpson

$$ y = \frac{(x - x_1)(x - x_2)}{(x_0 - x_1)(x_0 - x_2)}y_0 + \frac{(x - x_2)(x - x_0)}{(x_1 - x_2)(x_1 - x_0)}y_1 + \frac{(x - x_0)(x - x_1)}{(x_2 - x_0)(x_2 - x_1)}y_2 $$ $$ if \ (-h, y_0) (0, y_1) (h, y_2) \rArr \int_{-h}^{h}ydx = \frac{h}{3}(y_0 + 4y_1 + y_2) $$ $$ \rArr S = \frac{h}{3}((y_0 + 4y_1 + y_2) + (y_2 + 4y_3 + y_4) + \ldots + (y_{n - 2} + 4y_{n - 1} + y_n)) (n \ is \ even) $$

Error Bond: $K = |f’’{max}(x)|$ Riemann - $\frac{K(b - a)^3}{24n^2}$; Trapezoidal - $\frac{K(b - a)^3}{12n^2}$; $K = |f^{(4)}{max}(x)|$ Simpson - $\frac{K(b - a)^5}{180n^4}$

Trans between different variables

$$ \int_{C}^{g(x)}{f(t)}dt, assume \ F(t) = \int{f(t)}dt \rArr \int_{C}^{g(x)}{f(t)}dt = F(g(x)) - F(C) $$ $$ Taking \ derivative \ in \ both \ sides: \frac{d}{dx}{\int_{C}^{g(x)}{f(t)}dt} = \frac{d}{dx}F(g(x)) - \frac{d}{dx}F(C) $$ $$ F’(x) = f(x), F(C) \ is \ constant \rArr F’(g(x)) \cdot g’(x) - 0 = f(g(x)) \cdot g’(x) $$ $$ \therefore \frac{d}{dx}{\int_{C}^{g(x)}{f(t)}dt} = f(g(x)) \cdot g’(x), \frac{d}{dx}{\int_{h(x)}^{g(x)}{f(t)}dt} = f(g(x)) \cdot g’(x) - f(h(x)) \cdot h’(x) $$

HOW: How to integral - Technique

WHY: Why we use techniques to solve the integral problems?

  • The function cannot be antiderivatived directly.
  • The process of original function to integral is too challenging.
  • Direct integral cannot give us the answer.

WHAT: What is the techniques of integral

  • It could turn one function which cannot or is challenging to integral to a simple function
  • The tricks that we can use in the process of integral.

HOW: How to use the techniques to integral

If the function combines with its derivative: Substitution

Rules: $\frac{df}{dx} = \frac{df}{dh} \cdot \frac{dh}{dx}$

  • $\int{F’(g(x)) \cdot g’(x)}{dx}$

$$ u = g(x), du = g’(x) dx \rArr \int{F’(u)}{du} = F(u) + C = F(g(x)) + C $$

  • $\int{\tan{x}}{dx}$

$$ \int{\tan{x}}{dx} = \int{\frac{\sin{x}}{\cos{x}}}{dx} $$ $$ u = \cos{x}, du = -\sin{x} dx \rArr \int{\frac{-du}{u}} = - \ln{u} + c = -\ln{\cos{x}} + C $$

  • $\int{\frac{1}{x(x^2 + 1)}}{dx}$

$$ u = \arctan{x}, du = \frac{1}{x^2 + 1}dx, x = \tan{u} \rArr \int{\frac{1}{\tan{u}}}{du} $$ $$ v = \sin{u}, dv = \cos{u}du \rArr \int{\frac{1}{v}}{dv} = \ln{v} + C = \ln{\sin{u}} + C = \ln{\sin{\arctan{x}} + C} $$

  • $\int{\sec^4{x} \tan^3{x}}{dx}$ $$ \tan{\theta} = \sec^2{\theta} - 1 = \int\sec^2{\theta} $$

If the function combines with a simple function’s derivative: Int by part

  • Reduce Power: $\int{x \cdot \sin x}dx$
  • Eliminate complex function: $\int{\ln x}dx$

E.P. Find every function integral then int by part: $\int{\arcsin x \cdot \ln x}dx$

  • *$\int{\frac{1}{\tan^n{x}}}dx$ $$ \sec^2 - \tan^2 = 1 \rArr \int{\frac{\sec^2 - \tan^2}{\tan^n{x}}}dx = \int{\frac{\sec^2{x}}{\tan^n{x}}}dx - \int{\frac{1}{\tan^{n - 2}{x}}}dx $$ $$ \rArr \int{\frac{1}{u^n}}du - \int{\frac{\sec^2 - \tan^2}{\tan^{n - 2}{x}}}dx = \frac{1}{(1 - n)u^{n - 1}} - \int{\frac{\sec^2{x}}{\tan^{n - 2}{x}}}dx + \int{\frac{1}{\tan^{n - 4}{x}}}dx $$ $$ = \frac{1}{(1 - n)u^{n - 1}} - \frac{1}{(3 - n)u^{n - 3}} + \frac{1}{(5 - n)u^{n - 5}} - \frac{1}{(7 - n)u^{n - 7}} + \ldots (\pm \int{\frac{1}{\tan{x}}}dx) + C $$ $$ \rArr \int{\frac{1}{\tan{x}}}dx, v = \sin{x}, dv = \cos{x}dx \rArr \int{\frac{1}{v}}dv = \ln{|v|} + C $$

Other techniques (Not belongs to Integral)

Partial Fractions

$$ f(x) = \frac{A(x)}{B(x)} = f_1(x) + \frac{C(x)}{D(x)}, deg(A) >= deg(B) \ or \ deg(C) < deg(D) $$ $$ D(x) = (a_1x+b_1)^{p_1}…(a_ix+b_i)^{p_i}(u_1x^2 + v_1x + w_1)^{r_1}…(u_jx^2 + v_jx + w_j)^{r_j} $$ $$ \rArr \sum_{i, k}\frac{C_{i, k}}{(a_ix+b_i)^{p_k}} + \sum_{j, h}\frac{g_{j, h}x + h_{j, h}}{(u_jx^2 + v_jx + w_j)^{r_h}} $$

then Integral:

  • $\int{\frac{c}{(ax + b)^n}}dx$

$$ \int{\frac{c}{(ax + b)^n}}dx = \frac{c}{a} \cdot \frac{1}{(1 - n)(ax+b)^{n-1}} + C \ or \ = \frac{c}{a} \cdot \ln{|ax + b|} + C \ when \ n = 1 $$

  • $\int{\frac{gx + h}{(ax^2 + bx + c)^n}}dx$

$$ \int{\frac{gx + h}{(ax^2 + bx + c)^n}}dx = \int{\frac{gx + h}{(a(x + \frac{b}{2a})^2 + c - \frac{b^2}{4a})^n}}dx, u = x + \frac{b}{2a} \rArr \int{\frac{iu + j}{(au^2 + k^2)^n}}du $$ $$ (1) $$ $$ \int{\frac{iu}{(au^2+k^2)^n}}du, v = au^2 + k^2, \frac{1}{2a}dv = udu $$ $$ \rArr \frac{i}{2a}\int{\frac{1}{v^n}}dv \rArr \frac{i}{2a} \cdot \frac{1}{(1 - n)(au^2 + k^2)^{n - 1}} + C \ or \ \frac{i}{2a}\ln{|au^2 + k^2|} + C \ when \ n = 1 $$ $$ (2) $$ $$ when \ n = 1: v = \frac{u\sqrt{a}}{k} \rArr \frac{j}{\sqrt{a}}\int{\frac{1}{v^2 + 1}dv} = \frac{j}{\sqrt{a}}\arctan{v} + C $$ $$ *when \ n \neq 1: $$ $$ \int{\frac{1}{(x^2 + 1)^n}}dx, x = \tan{u}, dx = \sec^2{u}du \rArr \int{\frac{1}{\sec^{2n - 2}{u}}}du = \int{\frac{\sec^2{u} - \tan^2{u}}{\sec^{2n - 2}{u}}}du $$ $$ = \int{\frac{\sec^2{u}}{\sec^{2n - 2}{u}}}du - \int{\frac{\tan{u}\sec{u}\tan{u}}{\sec^{2n - 1}{u}}}du, i’ = \frac{\tan{u}\sec{u}}{\sec^{2n - 1}{u}}, i = \frac{-1}{(2n - 2)\sec^{2n - 2}u} $$ $$ \rArr \frac{x}{(2n - 2)(x^2 + 1)^{n - 1}} + \int{\frac{\sec^2{u}}{\sec^{2n - 2}{u}}}du - \int{\frac{sec^2{u}}{(2n - 2)\sec^{2n - 2}{u}}} $$ $$ = \frac{x}{(2n - 2)(x^2 + 1)^{n - 1}} + \frac{2n - 3}{2n - 2}\int{\frac{1}{(x^2 + 1)^{n - 1}}} $$ $$ \int\frac{1}{(ax^2 + b)^n} = \frac{2n - 3}{2b(n - 1)}\int\frac{1}{(ax^2 + b)^{n - 1}}dx + \frac{x}{2b(n - 1)(ax^2 + b)^{n - 1}} $$

Approx to limit

For integral $\int_a^b{f(x)}dx$, when there are some points that are not defined, we use $t$ to approx. the limit of those points:

$$ \int_a^b{f(x)}dx = \lim_{t \rarr b}\int_a^t{f(x)}dx $$

HOW: How to apply integral to reality

Rate - Differential Equations

$$ Imformal: \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{x}{y} \rArr ydy = xdx \rArr \int{y}dy = \int{x}dx $$ $$ *Formal \ Solution: \frac{d}{dx}{y(t(x))} = \frac{dy}{dt} \cdot \frac{dt}{dx} \lrArr \int{(y(t(x)) \frac{dt}{dx})}dx = \int{(y \frac{dt}{dx})}dx = \frac{y^2}{2} $$

  • Carrying Capacity:

$$ \frac{dN}{dt} = rN(1 - \frac{N}{K}) $$ $$ \rArr \frac{1}{N(K - N)} \frac{dN}{dt} = \frac{1}{K} (\frac{1}{N} + \frac{1}{K - N}) \frac{dN}{dt} = \frac{r}{K} \rArr \int{(\frac{1}{N} + \frac{1}{K - N})\frac{dN}{dt}}dt = \int{r}dt $$ $$ \ln{N} - \ln{(K - N)} = rt \rArr N = \frac{K}{1 + e^{-rt}} $$

$N$ is the population size, $r$ is the intrinsic growth rate, $K$ is the carrying capacity of the local environment, and $dN/dt$, the derivative of $N$ with respect to time $t$, is the rate of change in population with time.

$$ x\frac{d^2y}{dx^2} + 2\frac{dy}{dx} = 0 \rArr \int{(x\frac{d^2y}{dx} + \frac{dy}{dx})}dx = \int{-\frac{dy}{dx}}dx \rArr x\frac{dy}{dx} = -x $$

Arc Length

$$ L = \lim_{x_2 \rarr x_1}{\sum{\sqrt{(x_2 - x_1)^2 + (y_2 - y_1)^2}}} = \int{\sqrt{1 + y’}}dx $$ $$ * \int{\sqrt{(x^2 + 1)^2 + b}}dx $$

Areas

$$ A = \lim_{n \rarr \infty}{\sum_{i = 1}^{n}{\Delta{x}(f(x_i^\star) - g(x_i^\star))}} = \int_{x_1}^{x_2}{(f(x) - g(x))}dx = \int_{y_1}^{y_2}{(f^{-1}(y) - g^{-1}(y))}dy $$

Volume

$$ V = \int{A(z)}dz $$ $$ Cylindrical \ Shells(y-axis): V = \lim_{\Delta{x} \rarr 0}{\sum{h(x) \cdot \pi ((x + \Delta{x})^2 - x^2)}} $$ $$ = \lim_{\Delta{x} \rarr 0}{\sum{h(x) \cdot \pi (2x \Delta{x} + \Delta^2{x})}} = \int{h(x) 2 \pi x}dx $$

item.title: Calculus - Differentiate
item.description:
WHY

Why should we learn differentiation?

Find the rate: At (when), the rate at which (how) is increasing/decreasing by (what) (unit).

  • Analyzing function $f(x)$ is increasing/decreasing/constant on $(a, b)$
  • Analyzing points ($x = a$)
    • Critical point: $f’(x) = 0$ or $\nexists f’(x)$
    • Stationary point: $f’(x) = 0$
    • Relative/Local Extrema: $f’(x) = 0$ and $f’’(x) \neq 0$
    • Inflected point: $f’’(x) = 0$ - concave upward(>0)/downward(<0)

Why a function could be differentiated? - Differentiability

  • Limit

  • Continuous: $\lim_{x \rarr a}{f(x)} = f(a)$ ($\lim_{x \rarr a}{f(x)} = \lim_{x \rarr a^+}{f(x)} = \lim_{x \rarr a^-}{f(x)}$)

    • IVT (Intermediate Value Theorem): If $f(x)$ is continuous on $[a, b]$, then $\exist c \in [a,b], f(c) \in [f(a), f(b)]$
      • MVT (Mean Value Theorem): If $f(x)$ is differentiable on $[a, b]$, then $\exist c, f’(c) = \frac{f(b) - f(a)}{b - a}$
      • EVT (Extreme Value Theorem): If $f(x)$ is continuous on closed interval $[a, b]$, then $\exist c_1, c_2, f_{max}(x) = f(c_1), f_{min}(x) = f(c_2)$
    • Discontinuous points (Discontinuity)
      • Removable ~: $\lim_{x \rarr a}f(x) \neq f(a)$
      • Jump ~: $\lim_{x \rarr a+}f(x) \neq \lim_{x \rarr a-}f(x)$
      • Infinite (Essential) ~: $\lim_{x \rarr a^+}f(x)$ or $\lim_{x \rarr a^-}f(x)$ equals $\pm \infin$

  • Smooth: $\lim_{c \rarr 0^+}{\frac{f(a + c) - f(c)}{c}} = \lim_{c \rarr 0^-}{\frac{f(a + c) - f(c)}{c}}$

WHAT: Difference between differentiate and derivative

  • $\frac{dy}{dx}$ differentiate is a method to cut source function to know the tendency
  • $y’(x)$ derivative is that kinds of tendency.

HOW
